Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Metallic glass catalysts for energy conversion and storage
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the application of high performance catalysts for use in energy conversion/storage devices such as fuel cells and batteries. Successful commercialization will considerably advance nano-manufacturing in electrochemical energy conversion/storage and have a positive impact on a number of clean energy technologies. Typical customers for the proposed innovation include a broad spectrum of high-tech industries which will potentially benefit from commercialization of this technology. Some examples include fuel cell manufacturers, automotive industry, consumer electronics and energy storage companies. Superior performance of novel amorphous catalysts compared to state of the art suggests that this technology might be attractive core strength for a new company. As such, this I-Corps program will seek to understand whether a market opportunity exists around application of this technology and any potential spin-out company.

This I-Corps project is focused on addressing catalyst performance bottlenecks in energy conversion/storage technologies such as fuel cells and batteries. This will be achieved by replacing state of the art nanoparticle catalysts with novel amorphous metallic alloys. Metallic glasses are fully amorphous multi-component alloys with unique combination of properties and processing ability. They can be produced in a wide range of compositions that are not available in crystalline form and therefore their electronic and catalytic characteristics can be engineered to achieve superior performance. A self-supporting architecture will be used for these novel amorphous catalysts, which prevent the dissolution of support material and significantly improve durability. The success of this project will lead to commercialization of highly-efficient and low-cost catalytic materials for electrochemical energy devices. It will pave the way for new clean energy technology ventures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of this NSF I-Corps project was identification of commercialization opportunities for next generation nano-structured metallic glass catalysts and understanding the pain points associated with fuel cell catalyst industry. Nano-structured metallic glasses are attractive as high-performance electro-catalysts because they are highly tunable and can be synthesized in a wide range of inexpensive chemistries, allowing continuous control of their electronic and catalytic properties. This knowledge will have a transformative impact in clean energy storage/conversion technologies such as batteries/fuel cells and potentially lead to multiple start-up companies in addition to benefiting the existing automakers. This technology might be attractive core strength for a new company because of the superior performance of amorphous catalysts compared to state of the art. The major activities during the I-Corps program included customer discovery for next generation amorphous nano-catalysts, identification of key value propositions, and customer interviews to identify pain points and challenges. Based on extensive market research, a strong need was identified for a nano-manufacturing process capable of synthesizing a wide range of inexpensive amorphous metallic compositions. Some of the most significant results included objective identification of value propositions, customer segments, channels, key resources, and revenue streams for the technology. The value propositions identified during the I-Corps program are likely to be of interest in other disciplines including advanced manufacturing and environmental engineering. The I-Corps team got extensive training on lean start-up methodology and valuable insights into technology commercialization. Some of the learning on engineering and industrial entrepreneurship were incorporated in graduate and undergraduate classes. Several partnerships are expected as a result of the engagement with interested industries. The impact on physical resources included development of new nano-manufacturing techniques and characterization instruments. The impact on institutional and information resources included numerical modeling approaches, computational codes used in simulation of a vast array of catalytic materials, and data visualization software for K-12 education and outreach.


Last Modified: 01/05/2019
Modified by: Sundeep Mukherjee
